section.title: What solidMatter is and what it's not
section.p: solidMatter is a Web-Development-Framework in the first place.

section.title: JCR API only
section.p: You may incorporate the sbCR classes to access the repository via the JCR API in the context of your application.
section.caution: Not tested yet, there may be some unwanted dependencies. Also it's not the whole JCR API implemented, and there are things handled differently in sbCR!

section.title: sbCR Infrastructure
section.p: You may incorporate the sbCR classes to access the repository via the full sbCR API (including extensions) in the context of your application.
section.caution: Not tested yet, there may be some unwanted dependencies.

section.title: What is a Content Repository?
section.subsection: - compromise between speed and JCR compatibility - DB backed, access possible aside JCR API - some things adapted to PHP - added functionality leads to restrictions - Conclusion: not portable if using the full sbCR API

section.title: JCR vs. sbCR (Restrictions)
section.subsection: - only one workspace - more workspaces supported, but not connected
- no session-level permissions - but user-level authorisations
- does not support same name siblings

subsection.title: Shared Sets
subsection.p: sbCR supports shared nodes according to the JCR API. However, they always have the same name as it is stored in the node itself, and nodes are managed separately from the workspace hierarchy.
subsection.caution: As there is only one instance of a node created in the repository, a name change applies to all nodes in the shared set.

subsection.title: Content vs. Application Logic?
subsection.p: JCR itself only deals with the data structures stored in the repository, and to some extent also with the content logic (via constraints, references and the like). sbCR uses a slightly different approach, it also couples application logic with the nodes. This is achieved by describing the different actions that can be 'called' upon the nodes.

Actions are what drives any application, may it be the click on a button/link or submitting of a form. Every action results in a request sent to the server which sends a corresponding response. In a REST environment like the web, everything is built of actions a user can take, even if they are called (periodically) by an AJAX event.

The application design should be built according to this premise. You are free to use a different approach (TODO: see other chapters), but it is strongly recommended that you describe the objects of the application domain in terms of data and logic.

subsection.title: What is a View?
subsection.p: A view in itself is first and formeost nothing more than a conceptual idea of different means to approach an object. For example, think of a folder in an operating system: you can list the files contained in the folder, you can view them in a thumbnail view, or you could take a look at the folder properties. This is the exact same object-centric approach solidMatter uses to build up an application. But it doesn't stop there, a view may use several actions, e.g. a folder's properties may be displayed, edited or saved.

In the application context, views provide a way to group actions together logically, but also in regard of the codebase. Usually, there is one class for each view, and this class handles all actions that can called upon a node.
subsection.info: Each view defined on a nodetype MAY be displayed in the backend automatically (as a flag TODO: consider authorisation). This doesn't make sense on all possible views, so it's up to you to decide which views should be invisible, and what's the most sensible order to display the views in.

subsection.title: Think...
subsection.p: So, what are you trying to achieve? You want to build a simple blog, therefore the required functionality is easily imaginable:

ul.li: Admins should be able to create, edit and delete blog entries
Readers should be able to comment

subsection.p: There's also a small, well defined set of things you deal with:

subsection.title: Application Domain Objects
subsection.p: In order to build this application, you have to model the domain objects you are dealing with, as well as the operations performed on them. So let's take a look at the details...
A simple blog entry should at least contain the following information:

ul.li: the creator (if we assume it's a blog run by several people)
the date and time the post was created

subsection.p: It should also be viewable, editable, and deletable by the admins in terms of use cases. Also anyone can view an entry in the blog.
A comment has even less information attached to it in the simplest version:
In terms of functionality, anyone can post a comment, and admins should be able to view, edit and delete comments.

As we have seen, there are two objects in the applications domain we have to model. But wait, haven't we forgot something? As solidMatter is able to run several blogs, we have to model the application itself, too. This is just as easy, a blog doesn't need much information for a start:
The blog itself should be able to list all entries, so you can click on a topic and view all details and comments.

subsection.title: Next Step
subsection.p: So now you know what you're dealing with. Ideally, you'd now write down all requirements and think about details e.g., how long may a blog entry get? But we want to get something on the screen, so we'll skip this part and deal with the details later. Time to move to the implementation...

section.title: Preparation
section.p: As you are implementing a new application and not an extension module, you have to put all new stuff into a new namespace to seperate it from the other modules. Namespaces should start with a lowercase prefix that applies only to one entity (a person, a company, an organisation). Remember, you might not be the only one creating a blog application, e.g. all modules "owned" by the solidMatter project will start with "sb" (for "solidbytes"). "my" would be a badly chosen prefix in reality, but let's just call the application "myBlog" for now.
So you got the namespace, but you need a 'safe' name (all lowercase plus underscore) for it, too. This would be "my_blog" according to the guidelines.
A module has to provide several mandatory things, e.g. you have to store the scripts, locales etc. in specific folders.
section.info: You might need to create more folders depending on what you need to provide (custom icons, CSS stylesheets and the like). More details on the default directory structure can be found in $CHAPTER

subsection.p: First, you should create the nodetypes for your application. Luckily, there is already a comment nodetype that meets our expectations, sbSystem:Comment, so we'll leave that one out.

chapter.title: Coding Guidelines
chapter.p: In order to keep the code readable and consistent, there are a number of coding guidelines described in this chapter. You MUST stick to these rules if you are contributing to the solidMatter core or any of the sb*-modules (provided by respectively under development lead by solidbytes). You SHOULD stick to these rules if you are developing a 3rd-party-module for solidMatter.
chapter.info: Rules exist to be broken. No, seriously, there are exceptions from these rules, but keep in mind that they are very rare, and MUST serve the readability or have a really good reason.

section.title: Versioning
section.p: There are 5 types of versions to be maintained in solidMatter, Module- resp. release-, API-, locale-, theme- and file-versions. Versioning uses a fixed scheme, which MUST be followed even for 3rd-party-modules. The scheme contains information on major version, features, bugfixes and release states. Module (=release), API, locale and theme versions are not coupled in any way to source code versions.

ul.li: Subversion: 00-99 (increased with every release that contains added features or API changes)
Bugfixversion: 00-99 (increased with every release that contains bugfixes, this number is reset on changes to version or subversion)
Release State (optional): one of the following - alpha, beta, rc# (# is not limited)

section.title: Variable Naming
section.p: Variables SHOULD always indicate their proposed type as lowercase prefix, followed by the self explanatory name: "$prefixSelfExplanatoryName". The well-known Prefixes for scalar types are:

ul.li: cache: any kind of cache object

section.info:
Exceptions:
$_REQUEST/$_RESPONSE: global request/response in solidMatter
$i, $j, etc.: loop iterators
$e: catched exception

subsection.title: Indenting
subsection.p: Indenting SHOULD always be done according to best-practices (indenting codeblocks) using tabs. Each tab uses the equivalent space to 4 spaces.

subsection.title: Bracketing
subsection.p: All code blocks SHOULD be contained in brackets, even if they only consist of one command. The opening bracket SHOULD be on the same line as the control flow structure (for, if, while...).
subsection.info: There may be sensible exceptions to that rule, when a series of short commands (e.g. defines) occur or when the unary operator is used.

subsection.title: Comments and File Structure
subsection.p: The file structure, and along with it the basic commenting structure applies to all files that contain only one class.

section.title: Session Usage
section.p: The session can be used to store various information. This chapter explains what different modes of access exist.

subsection.title: Per Nodetype Settings
subsection.p: The keys for the information should be named like this: "module:nodetype:setting". Example:

ul.li: [FEATURE] ability to define views and actions on nodetypes
[FEATURE] each node may have tags assigned to it, tags are workspace-global
[FEATURE] each node may be rated, rates are stored with user information
